stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on finalizing the layout and enemy placement for Course 14, a level with a pencil and cardboard aesthetic. The majority of the stream was dedicated to a deep brainstorming session to design the course's retro level, ultimately settling on a unique Mario Paint-themed drawing minigame. He also briefly showed progress on Course 15 and led a chat collaboration to name it 'Forgotten Fortress'.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explains that the N64 Expansion Pak is not a technical necessity for large ROM hacks, but rather a shortcut used by older, less efficient tools to avoid proper memory management.
development_findings.quote: The reason ROM hacks used the expansion pack is convenience. For the older tools, it was just easier... instead of properly managing my memory I'm just gonna use the expansion pack.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates that all main content for the game will be completed in 2025, after which the team will have significant time for polishing.

The naming process for levels is a creative and collaborative effort, as seen when Kaze and his chat brainstormed names for the ice castle, settling on 'Forgotten Fortress' based on its atmospheric and emotional connotations.
development_findings.quote: Forgotten already feels cold to me, you know what I mean? Forgotten as a word is like dark blue, transparent, you know, especially when you put fortress behind it.

development_findings.summary: The design for the Course 14 retro level went through a significant creative struggle, starting with a Mario Paint concept, exploring alternatives like Dr. Mario, and ultimately returning to a refined Mario Paint idea involving a drawing minigame.
development_findings.quote: Maybe Mario Paint just sucks as a retro section. Ever thought about that?

development_findings.summary: The planned Mario Paint retro level will involve the player walking into paint puddles to color their feet, then walking on a giant canvas to trace and color an outline of Mario's face, with a star awarded based on a pixel-matching algorithm.
Kaze is waiting on cardboard-themed models of Donkey Kong and Peach from a contributor named Yuki for use in one of the levels.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes game design must respect the limitations of the hardware, citing GoldenEye's aiming controls on the N64 as a negative example of failing to do so.
context_findings.quote: When you make a game you need to be aware of the restrictions you have, and aiming with a stick fucking sucks. So that's a restriction you need to keep in mind.

context_findings.summary: Kaze moved from Germany to Canada in 2021 and expresses a strong dislike for his home country, particularly its politics, which he views as corrupt.
context_findings.quote: I moved to Canada because I needed to flee Germany. Germany fucking sucks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze received and accepted a sponsorship offer to stream Roblox for two hours for $135, demonstrating a pragmatic approach to monetizing his content.
Kaze prioritizes player experience, such as a stable camera, over preserving specific skips or tricks, as shown when he enlarged an area in Course 14.
context_findings.quote: The area needed to be bigger for the sake of the camera. That's one issue I hate in Mario 64 when that happens.

biobak.summary: Kaze is preparing the greybox model of Course 14 to send to Biobak, whose role is to add the final colors and textures, illustrating their collaborative workflow.

badub.summary: Badub was not mentioned in this stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina is slated to work on the outside area of the ice castle level (Course 15), indicating her involvement in level art and design.

key_stories.title: Designing the Mario Paint Retro Level
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to design a fun retro level based on Mario Paint. After considering and discarding several alternatives, he and his community developed a unique minigame concept where the player uses Mario to draw and color on a giant canvas.
key_stories.challenge: A retro-themed section for Course 14 needed to be designed, but the initial idea, Mario Paint, lacked obvious platforming gameplay, causing a creative block.
key_stories.process: Kaze first struggled with the Mario Paint concept, considering its music and art tools. He then pivoted to researching other pre-Mario 64 games like Dr. Mario. After finding them unsuitable, he returned to Mario Paint, where the idea of a giant canvas and drawing with Mario's feet was proposed and refined into a specific gameplay loop.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze, with input from his chat, developed a concrete concept for a drawing minigame where the player traces and colors a large picture of Mario's face on a canvas, with a scoring system based on pixel-matching.
key_stories.key_quote: Shit, how do we make anything interesting out of this?

key_stories.title: Naming the Ice Castle
key_stories.summary: During the stream, Kaze realized the ice castle level was unnamed. Through a collaborative brainstorming session with his viewers, he settled on the name 'Forgotten Fortress,' choosing it for its atmospheric and emotional feel over more generic options.
key_stories.challenge: The ice castle level, Course 15, did not have a name.
key_stories.process: Kaze initiated a live brainstorming session with his Twitch chat. Numerous suggestions like 'Frozen Fortress' and 'Polar Palace' were proposed. Kaze evaluated them based on their sound and feel, eventually selecting 'Forgotten Fortress' for its evocative, psychological weight.
key_stories.outcome: The level was officially named 'Forgotten Fortress' after Kaze decided it best captured the mysterious and cold atmosphere he envisioned for the level.
key_stories.key_quote: Forgotten already feels cold to me, you know what I mean? Forgotten as a word is like dark blue, transparent, you know, especially when you put fortress behind it.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned a backstory for the ice castle ('Forgotten Fortress') involving a village of penguins who are scared of a monster that has taken over.

open_questions.topic: Technical Implementation of the Drawing Minigame
open_questions.context: Kaze is developing a complex minigame for the Mario Paint level that will require a custom algorithm to detect how accurately the player has drawn Mario's face.
